title: How am I able to get out of a $250,000 lawsuit?
question: I was in a 3 car collision. I hit one car and then that car hit another. At the in end of it all, I was I was at fault. Now this person is sueing me through Larry H Parker. After a few months the law suit was settled. The third party is coming after me as well and this time the law suit is for $250,000 with Larry H Parker. The same person that the first party sued me from. Is this even possible. This person had time to make their claims and I think the third party waited for the first person to get payed out. Then he made his claims. I feel like I am being ambushed in which this case is over exaggeratting their personal debts instead of the actual estimate of his car. He's sueing for $250,000 on pain and sufferings. Is this even possible??? PLEASE HELP!!!!!!!
answers:
What attorney Koslyn stated is correct. There is nothing wrong with what is going on from the facts as you have stated.

What is puzzling is that generally, insurance companies will not settle cases unless all claims are made--that is they wait until after the statute of limitation has passed to know exactly all the claims pending and then they begin negotiations and to distribute the limits of the policy between all the claimants. Your insurance company must be there to defend you and so your best source of information about what is going on and what sort of a defense you should be expecting is them.

If your insurance company is not defending you--then something is majorly wrong and you should have a face to face conversation with a local attorney to figure out what aren't you being defended.

I hope this helps-

Nima Taradji

There's no conflict for this law firm to represent 2 different clients against you, and both collisions seem to be your fault. There's also nothing wrong about this firm waiting for 1 client's claim to settle before filing the 2nd client's claim.

But why is your insurance company settling these claims on a piecemeal basis, given this situation of your liabiilty to 2 parties? As I'm sure you know, you don't "get out" of a lawsuit, you defend it. Why isn't your insurance company providing you with a lawyer? Why aren't you asking your own lawyer what's happening?

It is permissible for Larry H. Parker's office to represent both parties. Actually, Larry Parker is retired and the firm still uses his name from what I understand. Any case can be settled at any time, so the timing you are complaining about is legal. Although they are suing for $250,000, it does not mean the case is worth that much. You also need to turn all these matters over to your insurance company. Ask them how much they have offered in settlement and how they arrived at the settlement offer. You may want to consult with your own attorney to review the case and advise you of the chances of a verdict over your policy limits. If you have assets and there is a chance of an excess verdict, it is strongly recommended you consult with your own private attorney.
